title: Asda hits 'nadir' as sales tumble 4.7pc in second quarter
text:

Tue, Aug 18, 2015, 13:37 BST - UK Markets close in 2 hrs 53 mins Asda hits 'nadir' as sales tumble 4.7pc in second quarter By Telegraph Reporter | Telegraph – 20 minutes ago 0.00 
The supermarket has endured the "worst storm in retail history", boss Andy Clarke (Toronto: CKI.TO - news ) says 
Asda chief executive Andy Clarke has declared he is "here to stay" despite the retailer posting a 4.7pc like-for-like sales decline in the second quarter of the year. 
Presenting the company's results on Tuesday, he labelled the turmoil in the supermarket sector "unprecedented" and said Asda had "hit its nadir". 
However Mr Clarke said the supermarket was already seeing "green shoots" in its third quarter, and insisted it retained the support and understanding of US parent company Wal-Mart. 
The sales decline in the second quarter accelerated from a 3.9pc like-for-like fall in the first three months of the year, which had been the retailer's biggest sales fall in five years. 
“We continue to navigate a steady course through the worst storm in retail history, despite another challenging quarter," said Mr Clarke. 
"Predicting that 2015 was going to be a volatile year I didn’t expect to report a positive sales figure, but I’m not distracted by the short-term picture. We have an enviably stable business with balanced books and the right strategy to return us to sales growth.” 
Alex Russo, Asda's chief financial officer, said that profits at the supermarket were flat in the second quarter, compared to profit declines at the other big UK supermarkets. 
“Behind the negative sales number lies a more positive story for Asda,” he said. “We are maintaining balance in an impulsive market and performing solidly in growth channels, maximising and accelerating our areas of strength while addressing areas of underperformance.” 
Asda has been battling Sainsbury (Amsterdam: SJ6.AS - news ) 's for the title of the UK's second biggest supermarket ; it currently holds a 16.4pc share of the grocery market, compared with Sainsbury's on 16.5pc and Tesco on 28.5pc. 
The 'big four' supermarkets - a group that also includes Morrisons - have been battling competition from discount grocers Aldi and Lidl, forcing them to make extensive price cuts . Asda began a five-year plan in 2013 to slash prices by £1bn. 
“We remain firmly committed to narrowing the price gap to the discounters,” Mr Clarke said on Tuesday. 
Seperately, Wal-Mart reported second-quarter earnings that missed analysts’ estimates after currency fluctuations and spending on employee pay rises dragged down profit.
